"\nText\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nEUROPEAN COMMISSION\nBrussels, 4.4.2016\nCOM(2016) 173 final\n2016/0091(NLE)\nProposal for a\nCOUNCIL DECISION\non the signing, on behalf of the European Union, and provisional application of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the Accession of Ecuador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nEXPLANATORY MEMORANDUM\n\n\n1.CONTEXT OF THE PROPOSAL\n\n\n\uf0b7Reasons for and objectives of the proposal\n\n\nThe attached proposal for a Council Decision constitutes the legal instrument for the signing and provisional application of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one part, and Colombia and Peru on the other part, to take account of the Accession of Ecuador .\n\n\nFollowing the withdrawal of Bolivia from the negotiation of an Association Agreement between the EU and the Andean Community, on 19 January 2009, the Council authorised the Commission to negotiate a trade agreement with those Andean Community countries (Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru) which shared our general objective of a balanced, ambitious, comprehensive and WTO-compatible agreement. Subsequently, negotiations for a multiparty trade agreement were launched in January 2009 between the EU and Colombia, Ecuador and Peru. Bolivia chose not to participate in the process. After 4 rounds, Ecuador suspended its participation in the talks and negotiations continued with Peru and Colombia only. \n\n\nOn 26 June 2012 the EU signed a Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru (the Trade Agreement). The Trade Agreement has been provisionally applied since 1 March 2013 for Peru and 1 August 2013 for Colombia.\n\n\nArticle 329 of the Trade Agreement lays down the provisions whereby other Member Countries of the Andean Community can become Parties to the Trade Agreement.\n\n\nFollowing the request by Ecuador to restart negotiations with the Union to become a Party to the Trade Agreement, negotiations were conducted between the Union and Ecuador in 2014. The negotiations for the Protocol of Accession by Ecuador to the Trade Agreement (\u2018the Protocol of Accession\u2019) were concluded in July 2014.\u00a0\n\n\nThe Commission informed EU Member States orally and in writing on the process of the negotiations with Ecuador via the Trade Policy Committee of the Council. The European Parliament has also been regularly informed on developments via its Committee on International Trade (INTA). The complete text resulting from the negotiations was circulated to both institutions. \n\n\nFollowing the initialling of the Protocol of Accession, an interim reciprocal arrangement was necessary for the establishment of a free-trade area with Ecuador in order to avoid unnecessary trade disruption. On the EU side, Regulation (EU) No 1384/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18 December 2014 on the tariff treatment for goods originating in Ecuador provides for the maintenance of the preferential duty rates applicable to goods originating in Ecuador on 12 December 2014 as from 1 January 2015. Regulation (EU) No 1384/2014 will expire on 31 December 2016.\n\n\nIn accordance with Article 329(4) and footnote 89 of the Trade Agreement, the EU- Colombia - Peru Trade Committee established in the framework of the Trade Agreement approved the Protocol of Accession of Ecuador at its meeting of 8 February 2016. \n\n\nConsistency with existing policy provisions in the policy area\n\n\nThe accession of Ecuador to the existing Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru, which is a balanced, ambitious, comprehensive and WTO-compatible agreement, reinforces the legal framework of the EU trade relations with this country and facilitates reciprocal trade and investment. It also incorporates Ecuador to the regime of joint rules and institutions established by the Trade Agreement. \n\n\nMoreover, accession to the Trade Agreement will provide an anchor for Ecuador's economic reforms and efforts to integrate the global economy, increase welfare and consolidate its growth with a view to improving the living conditions of its citizens. \n\n\nBy means of the Protocol of Accession, the Commission reached the objectives set out in the negotiating directives, namely to eliminate high tariffs, tackle technical barriers to trade, liberalise services markets, protect valuable EU geographical indications (GIs), open-up public procurement markets, include commitments on the enforcement of labour and environmental standards and offer effective and swift dispute settlement procedures. The resulting agreement goes well beyond WTO commitments and ensures a level playing field with competitors in the region. \n\n\n\uf0b7Consistency with other Union policies\n\n\nThe Protocol also contains a chapter on Trade and Sustainable Development that links the Trade Agreement to EU objectives in the field of labour, environment, and climate change. \n\n\n2.LEGAL BASIS, SUBSIDIARITY AND PROPORTIONALITY\n\n\n\uf0b7Legal basis\n\n\n\n\nThe legal basis for\u00a0this Council decision is the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, in particular its Articles 91, 100(2) and 207(4), first subparagraph, in conjunction with Article 218(5), thereof. \n\n\n\uf0b7Subsidiarity (for non-exclusive competence)\n\n\nThe common commercial policy, in accordance with Article 3 of the TFEU, is defined as an exclusive Union competence.\n\n\n\uf0b7Proportionality\n\n\nThis proposal is necessary in order to implement the Union\u2019s international trade and policy objectives towards Ecuador and Latin America in general, and as reflected in several EU-CELAC summit declarations. \n\n\n\uf0b7Choice of the instrument\n\n\nThis proposal is in accordance with Article 218(5) TFEU, which envisages the adoption by the Council of decisions on international agreements. There exists no other legal instrument that could be used in order to achieve the objective expressed in this proposal. \n\n\n3.RESULTS OF EX-POST EVALUATIONS, STAKEHOLDER CONSULTATIONS AND IMPACT ASSESSMENTS AND OTHER REMARKS\n\n\n\uf0b7Ex-post evaluations/fitness checks of existing legislation\n\n\n\nNot applicable.\n\n\n\n\uf0b7Stakeholder consultations\n\n\nNot applicable.\n\n\n\uf0b7Collection and use of expertise\n\n\n\nNot applicable. \n\n\n\n\uf0b7Impact assessment\n\n\n\nA detailed Trade Sustainability Impact Assessment (SIA) examining the Agreement's potential economic, social and environmental effects has been conducted and published in October 2009. \n\n\n\n\uf0b7Regulatory fitness and simplification\n\n\n\nThe signature of the Protocol is not subject to REFIT procedures; it does not imply any costs for the Union SMEs; and it does not raise any issues from the viewpoint of the digital environment. \n\n\n\n\uf0b7Fundamental rights\n\n\nThe proposal does not have consequences for the protection of fundamental rights in the Union. \n\n\n\n\n4.BUDGETARY IMPLICATIONS\n\n\n\nForegone duty is estimated to amount to EUR 80 million upon full implementation of the Agreement after ten years.\n\n\n\n5.OTHER ELEMENTS\n\n\n\uf0b7Nature and scope of the Protocol of Accession\n\n\nThe Protocol of Accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one part, and Colombia and Peru on the other part, establishes the necessary modifications to the Trade Agreement to take account of the accession of Ecuador. The Trade Agreement establishes the conditions for EU economic operators to take full advantage of the opportunities and the emerging complementarities between our respective economies. Over the course of its implementation, the Trade Agreement will fully relieve EU exporters of industrial and fisheries products to Ecuador from paying customs duties. It satisfies the criteria established in Article XXIV of the GATT 1994 (to eliminate duties and other restrictive regulations of commerce with respect to substantially all trade between the parties) i.e.: 99.5 % of EU exports are covered (100% of our trade in industrial products in 10 years; and around 90% of agriculture after 17 years). In addition, it will allow for the dismantling of several important non-tariff barriers. Ecuador will benefit from substantial new access to the EU market in particular for their key agriculture export: bananas, and the EU will grant 100% duty-free coverage for fisheries of Ecuadorian origin and liberalise 99, 9% of industrial tariff lines and 100% of industrial imports at entry into force. \n\n\nOn services and establishment as well as public procurement coverage, the agreement matches the ambition of the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru. It includes substantial commitments on all key sectors (notably financial services, telecommunications, transport) for cross-border supply and establishment in particular, while the EU's concerns in terms of temporary presence of natural persons for business purposes (mode 4) have been dealt with satisfactorily. In procurement, the EU has obtained the commitment of institutions at both central and sub-central level with appropriately low thresholds. \n\n\nThe Trade Agreement also establishes a set of disciplines which go beyond those agreed in the multilateral framework, notably on intellectual property (e.g. 116 EU geographical indications protected in Ecuador, data protection conditions clarified); sustainable development (the agreement is GSP+ equivalent or above on labour and environmental issues and contains specific commitments on sustainable fisheries); competition (disciplines on monopolies and State Enterprises \u2013 transparency obligations on subsidies); technical barriers to trade (WTO+ elements on market surveillance, transparency in regulation procedures and disciplines on labelling and marking); Sanitary and Phytosanitary measures (WTO+ measures on animal welfare, regionalisation, approval of export establishments, on the spot inspections and import checks) among others. In addition, via its accession Ecuador will participate in the Trade Committee as well as in a set of sub-committees which allow for consultations on specific trade concerns under its different titles. A key added value of the agreement is therefore to lock-in and promote \u2013 above and beyond those rules that derive from the WTO framework \u2013 openness policies and respect for internationally agreed best practices at the domestic level while securing a transparent, non-discriminatory and predictable environment for EU operators and investors in the region. The possibility of the EU to avail itself of the bilateral dispute settlement mechanism foreseen under the agreement will also contribute to this objective.\n\n\nThe Protocol should be applied provisionally, pending the completion of internal procedures for its entry into force. By the provisional application of the Protocol, the provisions of the Trade Agreement also apply provisionally, with the exception of Articles Articles 2, 202 (1), 291 and 292 thereof, as in the case of the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru\n1\n.\n\n\n\uf0b7Implementation plans and monitoring, evaluation and reporting arrangements\n\n\nUnder the general provisions of the Trade Agreement, the Parties undertake to continuously monitor the operation and impact of this Trade Agreement. \n\n\nEcuador will take part in the Trade Committee that is established in accordance with Article 12 of the Trade Agreement, which oversees and is responsible for the operation, implementation and correct application of the Trade Agreement.\n\n\nThe Trade Committee also supervises the work of all specialised bodies established under the Agreement, to which Ecuador will also participate as a Party to the Trade Agreement.\n\n\nThe following specialised bodies have already been established under the auspices of the Trade Committee. \n\n\n\uf0b7Market Access Subcommittee.\n\n\n\uf0b7Agriculture Subcommittee \n\n\n\uf0b7Subcommittee of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures\n\n\n\uf0b7Sub-committee on Government Procurement\n\n\n\uf0b7IPR Subcommittee.\n\n\n\uf0b7Customs Subcommittee.\n\n\n\uf0b7Subcommittee on Trade and Sustainable Development.\n\n\n\n\n\uf0b7Technical Barriers to Trade Subcommittee.\n\n\nAs far as reporting, in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 19/2013 the Commission committed to submit an annual report to the European Parliament and the Council on the application, implementation and fulfilment of obligations of the Agreement. Two such reports have been submitted, most recently on February 2016\n\n\n\uf0b7Detailed explanation of the specific provisions of the proposal\n\n\nThe proposal in articles 1 and 2 and 3 contains provisions on the signing of the Protocol on behalf of the Union, on the establishment of the instrument of full powers to sign the Protocol, and on its application between the EU and Ecuador on a provisional basis by the Union. It also contains provisions on the publication in the Official Journal of the European Union by the General Secretariat of the Council. \n\n\nArticle 4 specifies that the Protocol of Accession must not be construed as conferring rights or imposing obligations which can be directly invoked before European Union or Member State courts or tribunals.\n\n\nArticle 5 establishes the date of the entry into force of the Decision.\n\n\n2016/0091 (NLE)\n\n\nProposal for a\n\n\nCOUNCIL DECISION\n\n\non the signing, on behalf of the European Union, and provisional application of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the Accession of Ecuador\n\n\nTHE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN UNION,\n\n\nHaving regard to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and in particular Articles 91, 100(2), and the first subparagraph of 207(4), in conjunction with Article 218(5), thereof,\n\n\nHaving regard to the proposal from the European Commission,\n2\n\n\n\nWhereas:\n\n\n(1)On 19 January 2009 the Council authorised the Commission to negotiate a trade agreement on behalf of the Union with those Member Countries of the Andean Community which shared the aim to reach an ambitious, comprehensive, and balanced trade agreement. \n\n\n(2)On 26 June 2012, the Union signed the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part\n3\n (\"Trade Agreement\"). The Trade Agreement has been provisionally applied since 1 March 2013 for Peru and 1 August 2013 for Colombia.\n\n\n(3)Article 329 of the Trade Agreement lays down the provisions whereby other Member Countries of the Andean Community can become Parties to the Trade Agreement.\n\n\n(4)Negotiations for the Protocol of Accession by Ecuador to the Trade Agreement were conducted between the Union and Ecuador in 2014. The negotiations were concluded on 17 July 2014.\n\n\n(5)The text of the Protocol was approved by the Trade Committee of the Trade Agreement at its meeting of 8 February 2016.\n\n\n(6)The Protocol should be signed on behalf of the Union and it should be applied, on a provisional basis, pending the completion of the procedures for its conclusion. As a result of the provisional application of the Protocol, the Trade Agreement applies provisionally.\n\n\n\n\n(7)The provisional application provided for in this Decision does not prejudge the allocation of competences between the Union and its Member States in accordance with the Treaties.\n\n\n(8)The Protocol should not be construed as conferring rights or imposing obligations which can be directly invoked before Union or Member State courts and tribunals.\n\n\n(9)The Protocol should be signed,\n\n\nHAS ADOPTED THIS DECISION: \n\n\nArticle 1\n\n\n1.The signing of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the Accession of Ecuador is hereby authorised on behalf of the Union, subject to the conclusion of the said Protocol.\n\n\n2.The text of the Protocol is attached to this Decision.\n\n\nArticle 2\n\n\nThe Council Secretariat General shall establish the instrument of full powers to sign the Protocol of Accession on behalf of the European Union, subject to its conclusion, for the person(s) indicated by the negotiator. \n\n\nArticle 3\n\n\n1.The Protocol shall be applied between the Union and Ecuador on a provisional basis by the Union as provided for in Article\u00a027(4) thereof, pending the completion of the procedures for its conclusion. As a result, the provisions of the Trade Agreement shall be applied on a provisional basis by the Union as provided for in Article 330(3) thereof, pending the procedures for the conclusion of the said Protocol, with the exception of Articles 2, 202 (1), 291 and 292 thereof. \n\n\n2.The date from which the Protocol will be provisionally applied shall be published in the Official Journal of the European Union by the General Secretariat of the Council.\n\n\nArticle 4\n\n\nThe Protocol shall not be construed as conferring rights or imposing obligations which can be directly invoked before the Union or Member State courts or tribunals. \n\n\nArticle 5\n\n\nThis Decision shall enter into force on the date of its adoption.\n\n\nDone at Brussels,\n\n\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the Council\n\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The President\n\n\n\nLEGISLATIVE FINANCIAL STATEMENT FOR PROPOSALS HAVING A BUDGETARY IMPACT EXCLUSIVELY LIMITED TO THE REVENUE SIDE\n\n\n\n\n1.NAME OF THE PROPOSAL:\n\n\nCOUNCIL DECISION on the signing, on behalf of the European Union, and provisional application of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the Accession of Ecuador.\n\n\n2.BUDGET LINES\n\n\nChapter and Article: Chapter 12, Article 120\n\n\nAmount legislation is designed to ensure the correct application of all EU customs measures including the tariff preferences laid down in this Protocol of Accession, which also provides for the application of the necessary provisions of the Trade Agreement on the application of preferential rules of origin and administrative cooperation (Annex II), assistance with enquiries (Annex V), and the possibility, after consultations, of temporary withdrawal of tariff preferences in the event of frauds and irregularities involving preferential treatment (Annex III).\n\n\n5.OTHER REMARKS\n\n\nThis estimate is based on the average volume of imports over the period 2012-2014. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n(1)\nCouncil Decision of 31 May 2012 on the signing, on behalf of the Union, and provisional application of the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. gross amounts after deduction of 25 % of collection costs.\n\n\n\n\n\nTop  \n\n\n\n\n\n\nEUROPEAN COMMISSION\nBrussels, 4.4.2016\nCOM(2016) 173 final\nANNEX\nto the\nProposal for a Council Decision\non the signing, on behalf of the European Union, and provisional application of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement  between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the Accession of Ecuador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPROTOCOL OF ACCESSION\n\n\nto the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the accession of Ecuador\n\n\nTHE KINGDOM OF BELGIUM,\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF BULGARIA, \n\n\nTHE CZECH REPUBLIC,\n\n\nTHE KINGDOM OF DENMARK,\n\n\nTHE FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF GERMANY,\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF ESTONIA,\n\n\nIRELAND, \n\n\nTHE HELLENIC REPUBLIC,\n\n\nTHE KINGDOM OF SPAIN,\n\n\nTHE FRENCH REPUBLIC,\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF CROATIA,\n\n\nTHE ITALIAN REPUBLIC,\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF CYPRUS,\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF LATVIA,\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF LITHUANIA,\n\n\nTHE GRAND DUCHY OF LUXEMBOURG,\n\n\nHUNGARY,\n\n\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF MALTA,\n\n\nTHE KINGDOM OF THE NETHERLANDS,\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF AUSTRIA,\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF POLAND,\n\n\nTHE PORTUGUESE REPUBLIC,\n\n\nROMANIA,\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF SLOVENIA,\n\n\nTHE SLOVAK REPUBLIC,\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF FINLAND,\n\n\nTHE KINGDOM OF SWEDEN,\n\n\nTHE UNITED KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITAIN AND NORTHERN IRELAND,\n\n\nContracting Parties to the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, hereinafter referred to as the \u2018Member States of the European Union\u2019,\n\n\nand\n\n\nTHE EUROPEAN UNION,\n\n\nof the one part, and\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF COLOMBIA (hereinafter referred to as 'Colombia'),\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF PERU, (hereinafter referred to as 'Peru'),\n\n\nand\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF ECUADOR, (hereinafter referred to as 'Ecuador'),\n\n\nhereinafter also referred to as the 'signatory Andean Countries',\n\n\n\n\nof the other part,\n\n\nWHEREAS the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part (hereinafter referred to as the Agreement), was signed at Brussels on 26 June 2012 and some of its provisions have been applied pursuant to Article 330 thereof between the EU and Peru since 1 March 2013 and between EU and Colombia since 1 August 2013;\n\n\nWHEREAS the Treaty concerning the accession of the Croatia to the European Union was signed at Brussels on 9 December 2011 and entered into force on 1 July 2013;\n\n\nWHEREAS the Additional Protocol to the Agreement to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia (hereinafter referred to as 'Croatia') to the European Union has been signed by the European Union, Colombia and Peru at XXX on XXX;\n\n\nWHEREAS Article 6 of the Agreement states that \u201cFor the purposes of this Agreement, \u2018Party\u2019 means the European Union or its Member States or the European Union and its Member States within their respective areas of competence as derived from the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (hereinafter referred to as the \u2018EU Party\u2019), or each of the signatory Andean Countries\u201d;\n\n\nWHEREAS Article 7(1) of the Agreement states that \u201cthe provisions of this Agreement apply to the bilateral trade and economic relations between, on the one part, each individual signatory Andean Country and on the other part, the EU Party; but not to the trade and economic relations between individual signatory Andean Countries\u201d;\n\n\nWHEREAS Article 329 of the Agreement lays down the provisions to provide for an accession of other Member Countries of the Andean Community to the Agreement;\n\n\nWHEREAS the European Union and Ecuador have concluded negotiations on 17 July 2014, which was notified to the Trade Committee established under the Agreement on XX.XX 2014;\n\n\nWHEREAS Ecuador's accession to the Agreement is to become effective by means of the conclusion of a Protocol of Accession;\n\n\nWHEREAS for the purposes of Ecuador's accession to the Additional Protocol to the Agreement to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, the provisions of the Additional Protocol should be integrated into the provisions of this Protocol;\n\n\nWHEREAS the text of this Protocol of has been approved by the Trade Committee established under the Agreement in accordance with Article 329(4) of the Agreement;\n\n\nWHEREAS the Parties, in line with the above mentioned, have agreed to address the accession of Ecuador to the Agreement by means of the present Protocol of Accession. \n\n\nHAVE AGREED AS FOLLOWS:\n\n\nSECTION I\n\n\nCONTRACTING PARTIES\n\n\nArticle 1\n\n\nEcuador hereby becomes a Party to the Agreement, including the amendments thereto provided for in the Additional Protocol to the Agreement to take account of the accession of Croatia to the European Union. \n\n\nSECTION II\n\n\nPROVISIONS OF THE AGREEMENT\n\n\nArticle 2\n\n\n\n\nTitle, list of 'signatory Andean Countries', recital 11 and Articles 9, 11, 12, 13, 30, 41, 46, 48, 54, 57, 70, 78, 113, 120, 123, 124, 126, 127, 128, 137, 139, 142, 154, 167, 170, 202, 231, 232, 258, 278, 304 and 324 of the Agreement are hereby amended in accordance with the provisions of Annex I to this Protocol.\n\n\nSECTION III\n\n\nTARIFF ELIMINATION SCHEDULES\n\n\nArticle 3\n\n\n1.Subsection 3 ('Tariff elimination schedule of the EU Party for goods originating in Ecuador') as set out in Annex II to this Protocol shall be added in Section B of Annex I, Appendix 1 to the Agreement. \n\n\n2.'Tariff elimination schedule of the EU Party for goods originating in Ecuador' as set out in Annex III to this Protocol shall be inserted after the 'Tariff elimination schedule of the EU Party for goods originating in Peru' in Annex I to the Agreement. \n\n\nArticle 4\n\n\n1.Section D ('Tariff elimination schedule of the Ecuador for goods originating in the European Union') as set out in Annex IV to this Protocol shall be added in Annex I, Appendix 1 to the Agreement. \n\n\n2.'Tariff elimination schedule of Ecuador for goods originating in the European Union' as set out in Annex V to this Protocol shall be inserted after the 'Tariff elimination schedule of Peru for goods originating in European Union' at the end of Annex I to the Agreement. \n\n\nArticle 5\n\n\nEcuador shall be added to the title of Section A of Appendix 2 ('Entry prices of the EU Party') of Annex I to the Agreement, which shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'COLOMBIA AND ECUADOR'\n\n\nSECTION IV\n\n\nRULES OF ORIGIN\n\n\nArticle 6\n\n\nAnnex II to the Agreement shall be amended in accordance with the provisions of Annex VI to this Protocol. \n\n\nSECTION V\n\n\nAGRICULTURAL SAFEGUARD MEASURES\n\n\nArticle 7\n\n\n'Subject Goods and Trigger Import Volumes' corresponding to Ecuador shall be added as Section C to Annex IV of the Agreement ('Agricultural Safeguard Measures') as set out in Annex VII to this Protocol. \n\n\n\n\nSECTION VI \n\n\nSANITARY AND PHYTOSANITARY MEASURES\n\n\nArticle 8\n\n\nAppendix 1 ('Competent Authorities') to Annex VI to the Agreement shall be replaced by the provisions of Annex VIII to this Protocol.\n\n\nArticle 9\n\n\nThe following contact points and web-sites for Ecuador shall be added under letters A and B of Appendix 4 ('Contact points and web-sites') to Annex VI to the Agreement:\n\n\nA. Exterior (MCE)\n\n\n\nhttp://www.comercioexterior.gob.ec\n\n'\n\n\nSECTION VII\n\n\n\n\nTRADE IN SERVICES, ESTABLISHMENT AND ELECTRONIC COMMERCE\n\n\nArticle 10\n\n\nSection B of Annex VII ('List of Commitments on Establishments') to the Agreement shall be replaced by the provisions of Annex IX to this Protocol. \n\n\nArticle 11\n\n\nAnnex X to this Protocol shall be added as Section D of Annex VII ('List of Commitments on Establishments') to the Agreement. \n\n\nArticle 12\n\n\nSection B of Annex VIII ('List of Commitments on Cross-Border Supply of Services') to the Agreement shall be replaced by the provisions of Annex XI to this Protocol.\n\n\nArticle 13\n\n\nAnnex XII to this Protocol shall be added as Section D of Annex VIII ('List of Commitments on Cross-Border Supply of Services') to the Agreement. \n\n\nArticle 14\n\n\nSection B of Appendix 1 to Annex IX ('Reservations Regarding Temporary Presence of Natural Persons for Business Purposes') to the Agreement shall be replaced by the provisions of Annex XIII to this Protocol.\n\n\nArticle 15\n\n\nAnnex XIV to this Protocol shall be added as Section D of Appendix 1 to Annex IX ('Reservations Regarding Temporary Presence of Natural Persons for Business Purposes') to the Agreement.\n\n\nArticle 16\n\n\nSection B of Appendix 2 to Annex IX ('Reservations Regarding Temporary Presence of Natural Persons for Business Purposes') to the Agreement shall be replaced by the provisions of Annex XV to this Protocol. \n\n\nArticle 17\n\n\nAnnex XVI to this Protocol shall be added as Section D of Appendix 2 to Annex IX ('Reservations Regarding Temporary Presence of Natural Persons for Business Purposes') to the Agreement.\n\n\nArticle 18\n\n\nThe following enquiry point shall be added for Ecuador to Annex X ('Enquiry Points regarding Trade in Services, Establishment and Electronic Commerce') to the Agreement:\n\n\n'ECUADOR\n\n\n\n\nMinisterio de Comercio Exterior\n\n\nAvenida de los Shyris N 34-152 y Holanda\n\n\nEdificio Shyris Center\n\n\n\ndirecci\u00f3n.servicios@comercioexterior.gob.ec\n\n\n\nQuito, Ecuador'\n\n\nArticle 19\n\n\nAnnex XVII to this Protocol shall be added after Annex XI as Annex XI.a to the Agreement.\u00a0\n\n\nSECTION VIII\n\n\nGOVERNMENT PROCUREMENT\n\n\nArticle 20\n\n\nSection B of Appendix 1 to Annex XII to the Agreement shall be replaced by the provisions of Annex XVIII to this Protocol. \n\n\nArticle 21\n\n\nAnnex XIX to this Protocol shall be added as Section D of Appendix 1 to Annex XII ('Government Procurement') to the Agreement. \n\n\nArticle 22\n\n\nThe following shall be added at the end of Appendix 2 ('Media for Publication of Procurement Information') to Annex XII to the Agreement:\n\n\n'4. Ecuador\n\n\nProcurement portal of Ecuador: \n\n\n\nhttp://www.compraspublicas.gob.ec\n\n'\n\n\nArticle 23\n\n\nThe following shall be added at the end of Appendix 3 ('Media for Publication of Notices') to Annex XII to the Agreement:\n\n\n\n\n'4. Ecuador\n\n\nProcurement portal of Ecuador: \n\n\n\nhttp://www.compraspublicas.gob.ec\n\n'\n\n\nSECTION IX\n\n\nGEOGRAPHICAL INDICATIONS\n\n\nArticle 24\n\n\nThe following shall be added at the end of Appendix 1 ('Lists of Geographical Indications for Agricultural and Foodstuff Products, Wines, Spirit Drinks and Aromatised Wines\" to Annex XIII to the Agreement:\n\n\n'(d) Geographical Indications of Ecuador for agricultural and foodstuff products, wines, spirit drinks and aromatised wines\n\n\n\n\n\nGeographical Indication\n\n\n\n\nProduct\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCacao Arriba\n\n\n\n\nCocoa\n\n\n\n\n\n'\n\n\nArticle 25\n\n\nThe following shall be added at the end of the Appendix 2 ('Lists of Geographical Indications for Products Other than Agricultural and Foodstuff Products, Wines, Spirit Drinks and Aromatised Wines') to Annex XIII to the Agreement:\n\n\n'(c) Geographical indications of Ecuador for products other than agricultural and foodstuff products, wines, spirit drinks and aromatised wines\n\n\n\n\n\nGeographical Indication\n\n\n\n\nProduct Description\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMontecristi\n\n\n\n\nHandicrafts \u2013 Toquilla palm straw hat\n\n\n\n\n\n'\n\n\nSECTION X\n\n\nJOINT DECLARATIONS\n\n\nArticle 26\n\n\nThe joint declarations made by Ecuador and the EU Party set out in the Annex XX to this Protocol shall be inserted in the Agreement following to the list of Joint Declarations by Colombia, Peru and the EU Party. \n\n\nSECTION XI\n\n\n\n\nGENERAL AND FINAL PROVISIONS\n\n\nArticle 27\n\n\n1.This Protocol shall be concluded by the EU Party and each individual signatory Andean Country in accordance with their respective internal procedures.\n\n\n2.The EU Party and each individual signatory Andean Country shall notify in writing the completion of its internal procedures required for the entry into force of this Protocol to the all other Parties and to the Depositary referred to in paragraph 5.\n\n\n3.This Protocol shall enter into force between the EU Party and each individual signatory Andean Country on the first day of the month following the date of receipt of the last notifications foreseen in paragraph 2 with respect to the EU and the corresponding signatory Andean Country. \n\n\n4.Notwithstanding paragraph 3, the Parties agree that, pending the completion of the internal procedures of the EU Party for the entry into force of this Protocol, it may be provisionally applied. The provisional application of this Protocol between the EU Party and each individual signatory Andean Country shall begin on the first day of the month following the date of receipt by the Depositary of the following:\n\n\n(a)the EU Party's notification on the completion of the procedures necessary for this purpose; and\n\n\n(b)each individual signatory Andean Country's deposit of the instrument of ratification in accordance with its procedures and applicable legislation. \n\n\n5.Notifications shall be sent to the Secretary-General of the Council of the European Union, who shall act as Depositary of this Protocol.\n\n\n6.Where in accordance with paragraph 4, a provision of the Agreement is applied by the Parties pending the entry into force of this Protocol, any reference in such provision to the date of entry into force of this Protocol shall be understood to refer to the date from which the Parties agree to apply that provision in accordance with paragraph 4.\n\n\nArticle 28\n\n\nThis Protocol shall be drawn up in quadruplicates in the Bulgarian, Croatian, Czech, Danish, Dutch, English, Estonian, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Hungarian, Italian, Latvian, Lithuanian, Maltese, Polish, Portuguese, Romanian, Slovakian, Slovenian, Spanish and Swedish languages, each of these texts being equally authentic.\n\n\nArticle 29\n\n\nThis Protocol shall form an integral part of the Agreement.\n\n\nThe Annexes to this Protocol shall form an integral part thereof.\n\n\nIN WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned Plenipotentiaries, duly empowered to this effect, have signed this Protocol.\u00a0\n\n\n\n\n\nTop  \n\n\n\n\n\n\nEUROPEAN COMMISSION\nBrussels, 4.4.2016\nCOM(2016) 173 final\nANNEX\nto the\nProposal for a Council Decision\non the signing, on behalf of the European Union, and provisional application of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement  between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the Accession of Ecuador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX I\n\n\n1.The title of the Agreement shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n'TRADE AGREEMENT\n\n\nbetween the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia, Peru and Ecuador, of the other part'\n\n\n2.Ecuador shall be incorporated in the list of 'signatory Andean Countries' at the end of the list, after the Republic of Peru, and the list of 'signatory Andean Countries' shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n'THE REPUBLIC OF COLOMBIA, (hereinafter referred to as 'Colombia'),\n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF PERU, (hereinafter referred to as 'Peru'),\n\n\nand \n\n\nTHE REPUBLIC OF ECUADOR (hereinafter referred to as 'Ecuador'),\n\n\nhereinafter also referred to as the 'signatory Andean Countries',\n\n\nof the other part,'\n\n\n3.Recital 11 of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'CONSIDERING the difference in economic and social development among the Andean Countries as well as between the signatory Andean Countries and the European Union and its Member States;'\n\n\n4.Article 9(1) of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'1. This Agreement shall apply, on the one hand, to the territories in which the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union are applied under the conditions established in those Treaties, and on the other hand, to the territories of Colombia, Peru, and Ecuador, respectively(3).'\n\n\n5.A footnote shall be introduced in the last indent of Article 11 of the Agreement that shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n'\u2013\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0'person' means a natural(3a) or juridical person;\n\n\n(3a) In Ecuadorian Law, a \"physical person\" (\"persona f\u00edsica\") is referred to as \"persona natural\".'\n\n\n6.Article 12(3) of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n\n\n'3. The Trade Committee shall meet on a rotational basis, in Bogota, Brussels, Lima, and Quito unless the Parties agree otherwise. The Trade Committee shall be chaired by each Party for a period of one year, on a rotational basis.'\n\n\n7.A footnote shall be introduced in Article 13(3) of the Agreement that shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n'3. The Trade Committee may examine the impact of this Agreement on the micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (hereinafter referred to as \u2018Micro and SMEs\u2019) of the Parties(4a), including any resulting benefits.\n\n\n(4a) In the case of Ecuador, this examination may include the impact on the Actores de la Econom\u00eda Popular y Solidaria (AEPYS) (Popular and Solidarity Economy Stakeholders).'\n\n\n8.Article 30(a) of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'(a) Colombia and Ecuador may apply the Andean Price Band System established in Decision 371 of the Andean Community and its modifications, or subsequent systems for agricultural goods covered by such Decision;'\n\n\n9.Article 41 of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'For the purpose of this Section,\n\n\n\u2013'investigating authority' means:\n\n\n(a)with respect to Colombia, the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Tourism, or its successor;\n\n\n(b)with respect to Peru, the National Institute for the Defense of Competition and Protection of Intellectual Property, or its successor; \n\n\n(c)with respect to Ecuador, the Ministry of Foreign Trade, or its successor; and\n\n\n(d)with respect to the EU Party, the European Commission.'\n\n\n10.Article 46 of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'For the purposes of this Section, 'investigating authority' means:\n\n\n(a)with respect to Colombia, the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Tourism, or its successor;\n\n\n(b)with respect to Peru, the National Institute for the Defense of Competition and Protection of Intellectual Property;\n\n\n(c)with respect to Ecuador, the Ministry of Foreign Trade, or its successor; and\n\n\n(d)with respect to the EU Party, the European Commission.'\n\n\n11.A footnote shall be introduced in Article 48(1) of the Agreement that shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n\n\n'1. Notwithstanding Section 2 (Multilateral Safeguard Measures), if as a result of concessions under this Agreement, a product originating in a Party is being imported into the territory of another Party in such increased quantities, in absolute terms or relative to domestic production, and under such conditions as to cause or threaten to cause serious injury to domestic producers(9a) of like or directly competitive products, the importing Party may adopt appropriate measures under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in this Section. \n\n\n(9a) For the purposes of this Article, with respect to Ecuador, serious injury or a threat of serious injury to domestic producers will also be understood as serious injury or a threat of serious injury in an infant industry.'\n\n\n12.A footnote shall be introduced in Article 54(2) of the Agreement that shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n'2. If consultations under paragraph 1 do not result in an agreement on compensation within 30 days of the offer to consult, and the importing Party decides to extend the safeguard measure, the Party whose products are subject to the safeguard measure may suspend the application of substantially equivalent concessions to the trade of the Party extending the measure. (10a)\n\n\n(10a) With respect to Ecuador, the compensation in the form of concessions or suspension of substantially equivalent concessions shall take place only after three years of the imposition of the bilateral safeguard measure.'\n\n\n13.Article 57 of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'For the purpose of this Section, 'competent authority' means:\n\n\n(a)for Colombia, the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Tourism, or its successor;\n\n\n(b)for Peru, the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Tourism, or its successor; \n\n\n(c)for Ecuador, the Ministry of Foreign Trade, or its successor; and\n\n\n(d)for the EU Party, the European Commission.'\n\n\n14.Article 70 of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'1. The provisions of Article 59, subparagraph 2 (f), and Article 60 shall apply to Peru two years after the entry into force of this Agreement.\n\n\n2. The provisions of Article 60 (Advance Rulings), with the exception of advance rulings on tariff classification, and Article 62 (Authorised Economic Operator) shall apply to Ecuador two years after the entry into force of this Protocol.'\n\n\n15.A footnote shall be introduced in letter (a) of Article 78(1) of the Agreement that shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n'(a) on acceptance of a declaration of conformity from the Supplier(11a);\n\n\n(11a) Ecuador shall recognise a self-declaration from the supplier that the product conforms to the technical regulations of the European Union as sufficient proof of conformity with Ecuadorian technical regulations. This form of recognition shall remain in force until the EU Party and Ecuador agree on an alternative to replace it within the Trade Committee.'\n\n\n16.In Article 113 of the Agreement:\n\n\n(a)The following paragraph is inserted as paragraph (4):\n\n\n'4. In the sectors for which market access commitments are listed in Annex VII (List of Commitments on Establishment) by Ecuador, and subject to any conditions and qualifications set out therein, Ecuador shall grant to establishments and investors of the EU Party, with respect to all measures affecting establishment, treatment no less favourable than that it accords to its own like establishments and investors.'\n\n\n\n\n(b)Paragraph (4) becomes a new paragraph (5).\n\n\n17.In Article 120 of the Agreement:\n\n\n(a)The following paragraph is inserted as paragraph (4):\n\n\n'4. In the sectors where market access commitments are listed in Annex VIII (List of Commitments on Cross-Border Supply of Services) by Ecuador, and subject to any conditions and qualifications set out therein, Ecuador shall grant to services and service suppliers of the EU Party, with respect to all measures affecting the cross-border supply of services, treatment no less favourable than that it accords to its own like services and service suppliers.'\n\n\n(b)Paragraph (4) becomes a new paragraph (5).\n\n\n18.A footnote is introduced in Article 123 (b) of the Agreement that shall be replaced by the following\n\n\n'(b) \"specialists\" means persons working within a juridical person who possess uncommon knowledge essential to the activity, research equipment, techniques, processes, procedures or management of the establishment. In assessing such knowledge, account shall be taken not only of knowledge specific to the establishment, but also of whether the person has a high level of qualification referring to a type of work or trade requiring specific technical knowledge, including membership of an accredited profession (33a);\n\n\n(33a) The EU Party acknowledges that in Ecuador membership to an accredited profession is not mandatory.'\n\n\n19.The footnote to Article 124(1) of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'(35) For Colombia and Ecuador, the maximum length of stay for intra-corporate transferees is two years, renewable for an additional year. For Peru, the work contract may be up to three years. However, the length of stay for intra-corporate transferees is up to one year, renewable provided that the conditions which motivated its granting are maintained.'\n\n\n20.In Article 126 of the Agreement:\n\n\n(a)The following paragraph is inserted as paragraph (4):\n\n\n'4. Ecuador and the EU Party shall allow the supply of services into their territory through presence of natural persons, by contractual services suppliers of the EU Party and Ecuador respectively subject to the conditions specified in paragraph 5 and in Appendix 2 of Annex IX (Reservations Regarding Temporary Presence of Natural Persons for Business Purposes) for each of the following sectors:\n\n\n(a)legal advisory services in respect of public international law and foreign law; in the case of the EU Party, European Union law (hereinafter referred to \"EU law\") shall not be considered as public international law or foreign law;\n\n\n(b)accounting, and book-keeping services;\n\n\n(c)architectural services;\n\n\n(d)urban planning and landscape architectural services;\n\n\n(e)engineering services;\n\n\n(f)integrated engineering services;\n\n\n(g)medical (including psychologists) and dental services;\n\n\n\n\n(h)veterinary services;\n\n\n(i)computer and related services;\n\n\n(j)market research and opinion polling;\n\n\n(k)management consulting services;\n\n\n(l)services related to management consulting;\n\n\n(m)design services;\n\n\n(n)chemical engineering, pharmaceutics, and photochemistry;\n\n\n(o)services in cosmetics technology;\n\n\n(p)specialised services in technology, engineering, marketing and sales for the automotive sector;\n\n\n(q)commercial design services and marketing for the fashion textile industry, garments, footwear and articles; and\n\n\n(r)maintenance and repair of equipment, including transportation equipment notably in the context of an after-sales or after-lease services contract.'\n\n\n(b)Paragraph (4) becomes a new paragraph (5) and in turn, references to paragraph (4) in paragraphs (2) and (3) become references to paragraph (5).\n\n\n21.In Article 127 of the Agreement:\n\n\n(a)The following paragraph is inserted as paragraph (4):\n\n\n'4. Ecuador and the EU Party shall allow the supply of services into their territory by independent professionals of the EU Party and Ecuador respectively through presence of natural persons, subject to the conditions specified in the paragraph 5 and in Appendix 2 of Annex IX (Reservations Regarding Temporary Presence of Natural Persons for Business Purposes) for each of the following sectors:\n\n\n(a)Legal advisory services in respect of public international law and foreign law (in the case of the EU Party, \"EU law\" shall not be considered as public international law or foreign law);\n\n\n(b)architectural services;\n\n\n(c)engineering services;\n\n\n(d)integrated engineering services;\n\n\n(e)computer and related services;\n\n\n\n\n(f)market research and opinion polling;\n\n\n(g)management consulting services;\n\n\n(h)services related to management consulting; and\n\n\n(i)specialised services in technology, engineering, marketing and sales for the automotive sector.'\n\n\n(b)Paragraph (4) becomes a new paragraph (5) and in turn, references to paragraph (4) in paragraphs (2) and (3) become references to paragraph (5).\n\n\n22.The footnote to Article 128(1) of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'(39) The activities listed under subparagraphs (c) and (d) only apply between Colombia and Ecuador, on the one hand, and the EU Party, on the other hand.'\n\n\n23.The footnote to Article 137(1) of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'(41) In Colombia, the official postal operator or concessionary is a juridical person which supplies the universal postal service under a concession contract. The remaining postal services are subject to an expedited licensing regime administered by the Ministry of Information and Communications Technology. In Peru, the designated postal operator is a juridical person which under a concession granted by law, and with no exclusivity, has the obligation to supply the postal service in the whole country. The other postal services are subject to a permit regime granted by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications. In Ecuador, the official postal operator supplies universal postal services in the whole country under a license granted by law, and with no exclusivity. The remaining postal services are subject to a permit registration regime administered by the National Postal Agency.'\n\n\n24A footnote shall be introduced in Article 139 of the Agreement that shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n'This Section sets out the principles of the regulatory framework for telecommunications services, other than broadcasting (43), committed pursuant to Chapters 2 (Establishment), 3 (Cross-Border Supply of Services) and 4 (Temporary Presence of Natural Persons for Business Purposes). (44) (45) (45a).\n\n\n(45a) Between the EU Party and Ecuador, this Section shall also apply to value added telecommunications services. For greater certainty and for the purposes of this Section and Annex VII (List of Commitments on Establishment) and Annex VIII (List of Commitments on Cross-Border Supply of Services), for Ecuador and the EU Party, \u2018value added telecommunications services\u2019 are telecommunications services for which suppliers \u2018add value\u2019 to the customer's information by enhancing its form or content or by providing for its storage and retrieval.'\n\n\n25.The footnote to Article 142 of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'(49) This Article is not part of the commitments assumed between Peru and the EU Party under this Agreement without prejudice to the domestic legislation of each Party. For Colombia and Ecuador, on the one hand, and the EU Party, on the other hand, this Article shall only apply to telecommunication services that involve the real-time transmission of customer-supplied information between two or more points without any end-to-end change in the form or content of the customer's information.'\n\n\n26.A footnote shall be introduced in Article 154(1) of the Agreement that shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n'1. Notwithstanding other provisions of this Title or Title V (Current Payments and Movements of Capital), a Party may adopt or maintain for prudential reasons(52a), measures such as:\n\n\n(52a) The term \u2018prudential reasons\u2019 may include the maintenance of the safety, soundness, integrity or financial responsibility of individual financial service suppliers.'\n\n\n27.The footnote to Article 167(1)(e) of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'(55) For greater certainty, in the case of Peru and Ecuador, the execution of measures that prevent a monetary transfer through the equitable, non-discriminatory and good faith application of Peruvian and Ecuadorian Laws , respectively, relating to:\n\n\n(a)bankruptcy, insolvency, or the protection of the rights of creditors;\n\n\n\n\n(b)issuing, trading, or dealing in securities, futures, options, or derivatives;\n\n\n(c)criminal or penal offences;\n\n\n(d)financial reporting or record keeping of transfers when necessary to assist law enforcement or financial regulatory authorities; or\n\n\n(e)ensuring compliance with judicial or administrative orders or rulings in judicial or administrative proceedings;\n\n\nshall not be considered inconsistent with the provisions of this Title and Title V (Current Payments and Capital Movements).'\n\n\n28.Article 170 of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'1. In the case of Colombia, where, in exceptional circumstances, payments and capital movements cause, or threaten to cause, serious difficulties for the operation of exchange rate policy or monetary policy in Colombia, Colombia may adopt safeguard measures with regard to capital movements for a period not exceeding one year. These safeguard measures may be maintained beyond such period of time for justified reasons when it is necessary to overcome the exceptional circumstances that led to their application. In such event, Colombia shall present in advance to the other Parties the reasons that justify their maintenance.\n\n\n2. In the case of Peru and the EU Party, where, in exceptional circumstances, payments and capital movements, cause, or threaten to cause, serious difficulties for the operation of exchange rate policy or monetary policy in Peru or in the European Union, Peru or the EU Party may respectively adopt safeguard measures with regard to capital movements for a period not exceeding one year.\n\n\n3. In the case of Ecuador, where, in exceptional circumstances, payments and capital movements cause, or threaten to cause, serious difficulties to the liquidity of the Ecuadorian economy, Ecuador may adopt safeguard measures with regard to capital movements for a period not exceeding one year. These safeguard measures may be maintained beyond such period of time for justified reasons when it is necessary to overcome the exceptional circumstances that led to their application. In such event, Ecuador shall present in advance to the other Parties the reasons that justify their maintenance.\n\n\n4. The application of safeguard measures pursuant to paragraph 2 may be extended through their formal reintroduction in case of extremely exceptional circumstances and after having coordinated in advance between the Parties concerned regarding the implementation of any proposed formal reintroduction.\n\n\n5. Under no circumstance may the measures referred to in paragraphs 1, 2 and 3 be used as a means for commercial protection or for the purpose of protecting a particular industry.\n\n\n6. A Party adopting or maintaining safeguard measures pursuant to paragraphs 1, 2, 3 or 4 shall promptly inform the other Parties of their relevance and scope, and present, as soon as possible, a schedule for their removal.'\n\n\n29.Paragraphs (2) and (3) of Article 202 of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'2. The European Union and Colombia shall accede to the Protocol Relating to the Madrid Agreement Concerning the International Registration of Marks adopted at Madrid on 27 June 1989 (hereinafter referred to as the \u2018Madrid Protocol\u2019) within 10 years from the signature of this Agreement. Peru and Ecuador shall make all reasonable efforts to adhere to the Madrid Protocol.\n\n\n3. The European Union and Peru shall make all reasonable efforts to comply with the Trademark Law Treaty adopted in Geneva on 27 October 1994 (hereinafter referred to as the \u2018Trademark Law Treaty\u2019). Colombia and Ecuador shall make all reasonable efforts to adhere to the Trademark Law Treaty.'\n\n\n30.In Article 231 of the Agreement:\n\n\n(a)The footnote to paragraph (1) of Article 231 shall be replaced by the following\n\n\n'(72) For Colombia and the EU Party, this protection will include data protection of biological and biotechnology products. For Peru and Ecuador, the protection of the undisclosed information of such products shall be granted against disclosure and the practices that are contrary to honest commercial practices, in accordance with Article 39.2 of the TRIPS Agreement, in absence of specific legislation regarding thereof.'\n\n\n(b)A new footnote is introduced in paragraph (2) that shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n'2. According to paragraph 1, and subject to paragraph 4, when a Party requires, as a condition for approving the marketing of pharmaceutical or of agricultural chemical products which contain new chemical entities, the submission of undisclosed test or other data related to safety and efficacy, that Party shall grant an exclusivity period normally of five years from the date of marketing approval in the territory of that Party for pharmaceutical products, and 10 years for agricultural chemical products, period during which a third party may not commercialise a product based on such data, unless he/she presents proof of the explicit consent of the holder of the protected information or his/her own test data(72a).\n\n\n\n\n(72a) This provision shall apply with respect to Ecuador five years after the entry into force of this Protocol.'\n\n\n31.A new footnote is introduced in Article 232 of the Agreement that shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n'The Parties shall cooperate to promote and ensure the protection of plant varieties based on the International Convention for the Protection of New Varieties of Plants (hereinafter referred to as \u2018UPOV Convention\u2019), as revised on 19 March 1991(72b), including the optional exception to the right of the breeder as referred to in Article 15(2) of such Convention.\n\n\n(72b) At the moment of signature of the Protocol of Accession of Ecuador to this Agreement, the International Convention for the Protection of New Varieties of Plants of 2 December 1961, revised on 23 October 1978, is in force in Ecuador.'\n\n\n32.Article 258(1) of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'1.For the purposes of this Title:\n\n\n\u2013\u2018competition laws\u2019 means: \n\n\n(a)for the EU Party, Articles 101, 102 and 106 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, Council Regulation (EC) No 139/2004 of 20 January 2004 on the control of concentrations between undertakings (the EC Merger Regulation), and their implementing regulations and amendments;\n\n\n(b)for Colombia, Ecuador and Peru, the following, as appropriate:\n\n\n(i)domestic laws related to competition(76a) adopted or maintained in compliance with Article 260, and their implementing regulations and amendments; and/or\n\n\n(ii)Andean Community legislation applying in Colombia, Ecuador or Peru and its implementing regulations and amendments;\n\n\n\u2013\u2018competition authority\u2019 and \u2018competition authorities\u2019 mean: \n\n\n(a)for the EU Party, the European Commission; and, \n\n\n(b)for Colombia, Ecuador and Peru, their respective national competition authorities.\n\n\n(76a) For Ecuador, Article 336 of the Constituci\u00f3n de la Republica del Ecuador (Constitution of Ecuador) establishing the obligation for the State to ensure transparency and efficiency in the markets and foster competition, and the Ley Org\u00e1nica de Regulaci\u00f3n y Control del Poder de Mercado (Organic Law on the Regulation and Control of Market Forces).'\n\n\n33.The footnote to Article 278 of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'(81) Peru and Ecuador interpret this Article against the background of Principle 15 of the Rio Declaration on Environment and Development.'\n\n\n34.Paragraphs (1) and (4) in Article 304 of the Agreement shall be replaced by the following:\n\n\n'1. The Trade Committee shall establish at its first meeting a list of 30 individuals who are willing and able to serve as arbitrators. Each Party shall propose five individuals to serve as arbitrators. The Parties shall also select by mutual agreement 10 individuals who are not nationals (87) of any of the Parties, and who shall act as chairperson of the arbitration panel.\n\n\n\u2026.\n\n\n\n\n4. The Trade Committee shall establish, furthermore, additional lists of 15 individuals with sectorial experience on specific subjects covered by this Agreement. To that effect, each Party shall nominate three individuals to serve as arbitrators. The Parties, by mutual agreement, shall select three candidates to chair the arbitration panel who are not nationals of any of the Parties. Each party to the dispute may choose to designate its arbitrator among those proposed by any of the Parties for a sectorial list. When resorting to the selection procedure established in Article 303 paragraph 3, the Chair of the Trade Committee, or his/her delegate, may use a sectorial list upon agreement of the parties to the dispute.'\n\n\n35.Two footnotes are introduced in letter (d) and (e) of Article 324(2) of the Agreement that shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n(d) strengthening commercial and institutional capacities in this field, for the implementation of this Agreement(88a) and making the most of it; and\n\n\n(e) addressing the needs of cooperation identified in other parts of this Agreement(88b). \n\n\n(88a) Ecuador, underlines that such initiatives should also contribute towards the strengthening of production capacities and towards sustainable economic development of the Parties.\n\n\n(88b) In this context, Ecuador underlines the importance of also considering projects related to Title III, Chapter 4 of this Agreement.'\n\n\n\n\n\nTop  \n\n\n\n\n\n\nEUROPEAN COMMISSION\nBrussels, 4.4.2016\nCOM(2016) 173 final\nANNEX\nto the\nProposal for a Council Decision\non the signing, on behalf of the European Union, and provisional application of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement  between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the Accession of Ecuador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX II\n\n\nThe following shall be inserted after Subsection 2 in Annex I, Appendix 1, section B ('Tariff Elimination Schedule of the EU Party') as Subsection 3:\n\n\n'SUBSECTION 3\n\n\nTARIFF ELIMINATION SCHEDULE OF THE EU PARTY FOR GOODS ORIGINATING IN ECUADOR\n\n\n1.The base rate of customs duty and staging category to determine the interim rate of customs duty at each stage of reduction are indicated for each tariff line in the Tariff Elimination Schedule of the EU Party included in this Subsection (hereinafter referred to as the \u2018Schedule\u2019).\n\n\n2.For the purposes of the elimination of customs duties, interim staged rates shall be rounded down at least to the nearest tenth of a percentage point or, if the rate of customs duty is expressed in monetary units, at least to the nearest tenth of a euro.\n\n\n3.For the purposes of this Subsection \u2018year one\u2019 means the year this Agreement enters into force as provided in Article 330 (Entry into force) of this Agreement.\n\n\n4.For the purposes of this Subsection, beginning in year two, each annual reduction shall take effect on 1 January of the relevant year.\n\n\n5.If the entry into force of this Agreement falls on a date after 1 January and before 31 December of the same year, the in-quota quantity will be pro-rated on a proportional basis for the remainder of the calendar year.\n\n\nA. Tariff Elimination\n\n\nExcept as otherwise provided in the Schedule, the following categories shall apply to the elimination of customs duties by the EU Party pursuant to Article 22 (Elimination of Customs Duties) of Title III (Trade in Goods) of this Agreement:\n\n\n(a)customs duties on goods originating in Ecuador (hereinafter referred to as \u2018originating goods\u2019) corresponding to the tariff lines in staging category (hereinafter referred to as \u2018category\u2019) \u20180\u2019 in the Schedule shall be eliminated entirely and such goods shall be free of any customs duty on the date this Agreement enters into force;\n\n\n(b)customs duties on originating goods corresponding to the tariff lines in category \u20183\u2019 in the Schedule shall be removed in four equal yearly stages beginning on the date this Agreement enters into force, and such goods shall be duty-free, effective on 1 January of year four;\n\n\n(c)customs duties on originating goods corresponding to the tariff lines in category \u20185\u2019 in the Schedule shall be removed in six equal yearly stages beginning on the date this Agreement enters into force, and such goods shall be duty-free, effective 1 January of year six;\n\n\n(d)customs duties on originating goods corresponding to the tariff lines in category \u20187\u2019 in the Schedule shall be removed in eight equal yearly stages beginning on the date this Agreement enters into force, and such goods shall be duty-free, effective 1 January of year eight;\n\n\n(e)customs duties on originating goods corresponding to the tariff lines in category \u201810\u2019 in the Schedule shall be removed in eleven equal yearly stages beginning on the date this Agreement enters into force, and such goods shall be duty-free, effective 1 January of year eleven;\n\n\n(f)customs duties on originating goods corresponding to the tariff lines in category \u2018\u2013\u2019 in the Schedule shall remain at base rate; these goods are excluded from duty elimination or reduction;\n\n\n(g)customs duties on originating goods provided for in the tariff lines in staging category \u20180+EP\u2019 in the Schedule, shall be eliminated on the date this Agreement enters into force; the liberalisation concerns the ad valorem duty only; the specific duty linked to the entry price system applicable for these originating goods as laid down in Section A of Appendix 2 of this Annex shall be maintained;\n\n\n(h)customs duties on originating goods provided for in the tariff lines in staging category \u20180/5+EP\u2019 in the Schedule, shall be eliminated (i) on the date this Agreement enters into force, for the period between 1 May and 31 October and (ii) on 1 January of year six, in six equal yearly stages, beginning on the date this Agreement enters into force , for period between 1 November and 30 April, the liberalisation concerns the ad valorem duty only; the specific duty linked to the entry price system applicable for these originating goods as laid down in Section A of Appendix 2 of this Annex shall be maintained;\n\n\n\n\n(i)for the tariff lines in staging category \"AV0\" in the Schedule, the ad valorem element of the customs duty shall be eliminated on the entry into force of this Agreement;\n\n\n(j)for the tariff lines in staging category \"AV0-3\" in the Schedule, the ad valorem element of the customs duty shall be eliminated on the entry into force of this Agreement; the specific element of the customs duty shall be removed in four equal stages beginning on the date this Agreement enters into force, and such goods shall thereafter be free of any customs duty;\n\n\n(k)for the tariff lines in staging category \"AV0-5\" in the Schedule, the ad valorem element of the customs duty shall be eliminated on the entry into force of this Agreement; the specific element of the customs duty shall be removed in six equal stages beginning on the date this Agreement enters into force, and such goods shall thereafter be free of any customs duty;\n\n\n(l)for the tariff lines in staging category \"AV0-7\" in the Schedule, the ad valorem element of the customs duty shall be eliminated on the entry into force of this Agreement; the specific element of the customs duty shall be removed in eight equal stages beginning on the date this Agreement enters into force, and such goods shall thereafter be free of any customs duty;\n\n\n(m)the following customs duty on originating goods corresponding to the tariff lines in staging category \u2018SP1' in the Schedule shall apply:\n\n\n\n\n\nYear\n\n\n\n\nCustoms duty\n\n\n(EUR/t.)\n\n\n\n\nTrigger import volume\n\n\n(Metric Tonnes)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFrom 1 January until 31 December 2014\n\n\n\n\n118\n\n\n\n\n1 566 772\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFrom 1 January until 31 December 2015\n\n\n\n\n111\n\n\n\n\n1 645 111\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFrom 1 January until 31 December 2016\n\n\n\n\n104\n\n\n\n\n1 723 449\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFrom 1 January until 31 December 2017\n\n\n\n\n97\n\n\n\n\n1 801 788\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFrom 1 January until 31 December 2018\n\n\n\n\n90\n\n\n\n\n1 880 127\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFrom 1 January until 31 December 2019\n\n\n\n\n83\n\n\n\n\n1 957 500\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAs from 1 January 2020\n\n\n\n\n75\n\n\n\n\nNot applicable \n\n\n\n\n\nThe preferential customs duties indicated in the table shall apply from the date of the entry into force of this Agreement; the duties shall not be retroactively reduced;\n\n\nIn 2019, the EU Party and Ecuador shall examine the improvement of tariff liberalisation of goods included in staging category \u2018SP1\u2019;\n\n\nA stabilisation clause will be based on the following elements:\n\n\n(i)a trigger import volume is set for imports of originating goods provided for in the tariff lines in staging category \u2018SP1\u2019 for each of the years during the transition period, as indicated in the third column of the table above;\n\n\n(ii)once the trigger volume is met during the corresponding calendar year, the EU Party may temporarily suspend the preferential customs duty applicable during that same year for a period of time not exceeding three months, and not going beyond the end of the corresponding calendar year;\n\n\n(iii)in the event that the EU Party suspends the said preferential customs duty, the EU Party shall apply the least of the base rate or the Most Favoured Nation (hereinafter referred to as \u2018MFN\u2019) duty that will apply at the time this action will be taken;\n\n\n(iv)in the event that the EU Party applies the actions mentioned under paragraphs (ii) and (iii), the EU Party shall immediately enter into consultations with Ecuador in order to analyse and evaluate the situation on the basis of available factual data;\n\n\n(v)the measures mentioned under paragraphs (ii) and (iii) may be applicable only during the transition period ending on 31 December 2019;\n\n\n(n)goods originating in Ecuador corresponding to the tariff lines in categories \u2018GC\u2019, \u2018MM\u2019, \u2018MZ\u2019, \u2018RI\u2019, \u2018MC\u2019, \u2018RM\u2019, \u2018SC1\u2019, \u2018SC2\u2019, \u2018SR\u2019 and \u2018SP\u2019 shall be liberalised within a tariff quota under the conditions laid down in point B of this Subsection.\n\n\nB. Tariff Quotas for specific goods\n\n\nThe following tariff concessions shall apply as from the date of entry into force of this Agreement on an annual basis to imports into the EU Party of originating goods.\n\n\nThe EU Party shall allow duty-free imports of the following quantities and goods:\n\n\n(a)an aggregate quantity 500 metric tonnes of goods listed in category \u2018GC\u2019;\n\n\n(b)an aggregate quantity of 100 metric tonnes of goods listed in category \u2018MM\u2019;\n\n\n\n\n(c)an aggregate quantity of 37 000 metric tonnes, with an increase by 1 110 metric tonnes each year, of goods listed in category \u2018MZ\u2019;\n\n\n(d)an aggregate quantity of 5 000 metric tonnes of goods listed in category \u2018RI\u2019\n1\n;\n\n\n(e)an aggregate quantity of 3 000 metric tonnes of goods listed in category \u2018MC\u2019;\n\n\n(f)an aggregate quantity of 250 hl of pure alcohol equivalent, with an increase by 10 hl each year, of goods listed in category \u2018RM\u2019;\n\n\n(g)an aggregate quantity of 400 metric tonnes of goods listed in category \u2018SC1\u2019;\n\n\n(h)an aggregate quantity of 300 metric tonnes of goods listed in category \u2018SC2\u2019;\n\n\n(i)an aggregate quantity of 15 000 metric tonnes, with an increase by 450 metric tonnes each year, of goods listed in category \u2018SR\u2019 (raw sugar and panela).\n\n\n(j)an aggregate quantity of 10 000 metric tonnes expressed in raw sugar equivalent, with an increase by 150 metric tonnes each year, of goods listed in category \u2018SP\u2019 (raw sugar of the standard quality with a yield in white sugar of 92%).\n\n\nTARIFF ELIMINATION SCHEDULE OF THE EU PARTY\n\n\nGeneral notes\n\n\nRelation with the Combined Nomenclature (hereinafter referred to as the \u2018CN\u2019) of the European Union: The provisions of this Schedule are generally expressed in terms of the CN, and the interpretation of the provisions of this Schedule, including the goods coverage of subheadings of this Schedule, shall be governed by the General Notes, Section Notes, and Chapter Notes of the CN. To the extent that provisions of this Schedule are identical to the corresponding provisions of the CN, the provisions of this Schedule shall have the same meaning as the corresponding provisions of the CN.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(1)\n5 years after entry into force of the Agreement the EU and Ecuador shall examine the possibility to improve the market access of this product.\n\n\n\n\n\nTop (excl. roughly shaped blocks of wood for the manufacture of pipes)\n\n\n\n\n2,7\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n96151100\n\n\n\n\nCombs, hair-slides and the like of hard rubber or plastics\n\n\n\n\n2,7\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n96151900\n\n\n\n\nCombs, hair-slides and the like (excl. of hard rubber or plastics)\n\n\n\n\n2,7\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n96159000\n\n\n\n\nHairpins, curling pins, curling grips, hair-curlers and the like, and parts thereof, n.e.s. (excl. electro-thermic appliances of heading 8516)\n\n\n\n\n2,7\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n96161010\n\n\n\n\nScent sprays and similar toilet sprays (excl. coin or preparations\n\n\n\n\n2,7\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n96170011\n\n\n\n\nVacuum flasks and other vacuum vessels, having a capacity of <= 0,75 l\n\n\n\n\n6,7\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n96170019\n\n\n\n\nVacuum flasks and other vacuum vessels, having a capacity of > 0,75 l\n\n\n\n\n6,7\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n96170090\n\n\n\n\nParts of vacuum flasks and other vacuum vessels (excl. glass inners)\n\n\n\n\n6,7\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n96180000\n\n\n\n\nTailors\u2019 dummies and other lay figures, automata and other animated displays used for shop window dressing (excl. the articles actually on display, educational models and toy dolls)\n\n\n\n\n1,7\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n97011000\n\n\n\n\nPaintings, e.g. oil paintings, watercolours and pastels, and drawings executed entirely by hand (excl. technical drawings and the like of heading 4906, and hand-painted or hand-decorated manufactured articles)\n\n\n\n\nFree\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n97019000\n\n\n\n\nCollages and similar decorative plaques\n\n\n\n\nFree\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n97020000\n\n\n\n\nOriginal engravings, prints and lithographs\n\n\n\n\nFree\n\n\n\n\n0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n97030000\n\n\n\n\nOriginal sculptures and
